questions.question: Question 1: Gestational hypertension is defined as:
questions.explanation:
Gestational hypertension is defined as BP >140/90 after 20 weeks of gestation. Hypertension in pregnancy is defined as BP of >140/90 mmHg measured 2 times with at least a 
4-hour interval. Proteinuria is not an essential criterion to define pre-eclampsia. Pre-eclampsia is hypertension with any of the following features: • Proteinuria • Thrombocytopenia 476 
Sold by @itachibot • Renal insufficiency • Liver involvement • Cerebral symptoms • Pulmonary edema. Note: A normotensive pregnant woman may have an acute increase in BP from baseline levels and 
develop eclamptic seizures/HELLP syndrome, despite being normotensive. This condition is 
known as delta hypertension. Gestational hypertensio 
n Pre-eclampsia 
Chronic hypertension in p 
regnancy After 20 weeks of pregnan 
cy Before 20 weeks of gestati 
on Rise in BP 
After 20 weeks of pregn 
ancy Absent Proteinuria 
Absent 
May be present:>300 mg i 
n 24 hrs urine>30 mg/dl i

’rine dipstick 2+ Does not return to normal Fall in BP to normal lev

questions.question: Question 2: What is the minimum cut-off for defining proteinuria in a random urine sample?
questions.explanation: The cut-off for defining proteinuria is 30 mg/dl (0.3 g/L) in a random urine sample. Proteinuria in preeclampsia is also defined by: • 0.3 g protein in a 24-hour urine specimen. • Random urine protein: creatinine ratio (PCR) 0.3 mg protein/mg creatinine • Protein 1+ on urine dipstick A urine dipstick is used only if the above quantitative methods are not available. Note: Proteinuria is not an essential criterion to define pre-eclampsia.

questions.question: Question 3: In a normal pregnancy, when does the remodeling of spiral arteries begin?
questions.explanation:
In a normal pregnancy, the remodeling of spiral arteries begins at 12 weeks. Remodeling of arteries includes invasion of arteries by trophoblasts that convert them from 
low-flow, high-resistance to high-flow, low-resistance vessels. These modified vessels are more 
capable of meeting the demands of the developing fetus. ’teroplacental vessel development takes place in two stages: The first stage occurs before 12 weeks post-fertilization. During this stage, invasion of spiral 
arteries up to myometrium occurs. 477 
Sold by @itachibot The second stage occurs between 12-16 weeks. It involves invasion of the endovascular 
trophoblasts into the intra-myometrial segments of spiral arteries. Interstitial 
trophoblasts surround the arteries. Incomplete trophoblastic invasion leads to pregnancy-induced hypertension (PIH) where the 
vessels remain in a state of high resistance leading to placental ischemia and release of 
inflammatory mediators and vasoactive substances leading to endothelial injury. As the second stage of invasion occurs by 18 weeks, PIH develops after 20 weeks of pregnancy.

questions.question:
Question 4: A 28-year-old G2P1 patient at 17 weeks of gestation comes for a routine antenatal visit. Her 
blood pressure is 142/94 mm of Hg. A repeat blood pressure after 4 hours is measured to be 
148/92 mm Hg. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
In the above scenario of hypertension in a patient with gestational age <20 weeks, the diagnosis 
is chronic hypertension. Chronic hypertension is diagnosed when the patient is a known hypertensive (or) BP > 140/90 
mmHg before 20 weeks of gestation. Gestational hypertension and preeclampsia are only diagnosed after 20 weeks of gestation.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following does not put a patient at an increased risk for preeclampsia?
questions.explanation:
Smoking is not a risk factor for pre-eclampsia rather it is protective. Although smoking during pregnancy causes various adverse pregnancy outcomes, it is associated 
with a reduced risk for hypertension in pregnancy. Risk factors for pre-eclampsia are: • Previous history of pre-eclampsia • Primigravida: young or elderly • Family history: Hypertension, pre-eclampsia. • Placental abnormalities: • Hyperplacentosis: excessive exposure to chorionic villi (molar pregnancy, twins, diabetes) • Placental ischemia • Thrombophilias: APLA, Protein C, Protein S deficiency, Factor V laden mutation, 
homocysteinemia • Twin pregnancy • Molar pregnancy • Rh-negative pregnancy • New paternity - A new partner for subsequent pregnancies 478 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following does not occur in patients developing pre-eclampsia?

options.a: Abnormal trophoblastic invasion of uterine vessels
options.b: Maladaptive immunological tolerance to fetal antigens
options.c: Maladaptation to cardiovascular changes of normal pregnancy
options.d: Increased placental perfusion due to inflammation

questions.explanation:
Placental perfusion is reduced in patients developing pre-eclampsia. The development of pre-eclampsia may be explained by: • Abnormal trophoblastic invasion of uterine vessels, leading to decreased placental perfusion. • Maternal inflammatory response directed against foreign fetal antigens leading to 
immunological maladaptation. • Maternal maladaptation to cardiovascular and inflammatory changes of normal pregnancy. • Genetic factors and epigenetic influences.

questions.question:
Question 7: Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of patients with an 
increased risk of pre-eclampsia?

options.a: Low dose aspirin may reduce severity of disease
options.b: Calcium supplementation above RDA reduces the incidence
options.c: Treatment with magnesium lowers endothelin-1 concentrates
options.d: Megadoses of vitamin C has no proven benefit

questions.explanation:
Calcium supplementation above the RDA does not reduce the incidence of pre-eclampsia. However, women who have a calcium-deficient state may benefit from calcium supplementation 
to reduce their risk of preeclampsia. Prophylactic measures for the prevention of pre-eclampsia include low-dose aspirin 
administration (50–150 mg/day). It is started after the 1st trimester, continued throughout 
pregnancy, and is to be stopped 7 days before labor. Magnesium administration may be beneficial as it lowers endothelin-1 concentrates. There is no role of a low salt diet, anti-oxidants, or vitamin C.

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following statements is false regarding the pathogenesis of pre-eclampsia?

options.a: Vascular sensitivity to angiotensin 2 is increased
options.c: There is an increase in sFlt -1 levels
options.d: A decrease in the level of soluble endoglin is seen

questions.explanation:
In pre-eclampsia, there is an increase in the level of soluble endoglin. Excessive amounts of antiangiogenic factors, increased sensitivity to angiotensin, and lowered 
angiotensinase levels worsen hypoxia at the uteroplacental interface. Trophoblast of women who develop preeclampsia overproduces at least two antiangiogenic 
peptides that enter the maternal circulation. They increase months before clinical preeclampsia 
develops. • Soluble endoglin (sEng) is derived from the placenta and blocks endothelial nitric 
oxide-dependent vasodilatation. It also inhibits various TGF isoforms from binding to 
endothelial receptors. • Soluble Fms-like tyrosine kinase 1 (sFlt-1) is a variant of the Flt-1 receptor for placental growth 
factor (PlGF) and for VEGF. Increased maternal sFlt-1 levels inactivate and decrease circulating 
free PlGF and VEGF concentrations, leading to endothelial dysfunction.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 24-year-old primigravida at 22 weeks of gestation came for a regular antenatal checkup. 
Her BP is 152/96mmHg. ’rine analysis shows proteinuria of 3+. All of the following would be 
consistent with her probable diagnosis, except:
questions.explanation:
479 
Sold by @itachibot The given clinical picture is suggestive of pre-eclampsia and low fibronectin is not a feature of 
pre-eclampsia. Features associated with pre-eclampsia: • Fibronectin is a glycoprotein associated with vascular endothelial cell basement membrane and 
is elevated in women with preeclampsia. • Thrombocytopenia (HELLP syndrome) • Hemolysis (HELLP syndrome) • Increased hemoglobin, caused by a decrease in plasma volume. Hemoconcentration is a hallmark of eclampsia. In preeclampsia, hemoconcentration is present 
but usually not marked.

questions.question: Question 10: Which finding is most likely to be seen in a patient with pre-eclampsia?
questions.explanation:
Decreased GFR is seen in pre-eclampsia. During normal pregnancy, renal blood flow and GFR are increased. However, in pre-eclampsia, 
renal blood flow and GFR decrease due to increased renal afferent arteriolar resistance. The 
hallmark renal lesion is glomerular endotheliosis. Diminished filtration causes serum creatinine 
levels and plasma uric acid concentration levels to rise. The elevation is also due to enhanced 
tubular reabsorption. The most common system involved in pre-eclampsia is the renal system. Several studies have demonstrated that pre-eclampsia is associated with low urinary calcium. This 
is often used as a predictive test.

questions.question: Question 11: Ophthalmic manifestations in patients with preeclampsia syndrome include all, except:

options.b: Central vision loss due to temporary scotoma
options.c: Permanent visual loss due to retinal artery occlusion
options.d: Permanent blindness due to serous retinal detachment

questions.explanation:
Serous retinal detachment does not cause permanent visual loss. The most common visual symptom of preeclampsia is scotoma. Blindness can be due to occipital cortex edema, Purtscher’s retinopathy (retinal ischemia), or 
retinal detachment. The blindness is mostly reversible and corrects automatically after delivery. Retinal artery occlusion sometimes causes permanent vision loss.

questions.question:
Question 12: A patient, diagnosed with preeclampsia was brought to the emergency room with three 
episodes of generalized tonic-clonic seizures, urinary incontinence, and altered sensorium for 
3 hours. After stabilization, an MRI revealed the following findings. Which of the following is 469 
Sold by @itachibot true regarding this condition?

options.a: Anterior circulation is most commonly involved
options.b: This lesions may be seen in most pre-eclampsia patients

questions.explanation:
The above clinical scenario and radiological image are suggestive of posterior reversible 
leukoencephalopathy syndrome (PRES). This condition is usually reversible. Endothelial dysfunction and cerebral autoregulation failure are implicated as etiologies of 
PRES. PRES lesions are almost universal in women with eclampsia but less frequent in 480 
Sold by @itachibot pre-eclampsia. PRES is characterized by the following: • Severe headaches • Altered sensorium • Seizures • Visual disturbances. Radiological findings in PRES: • Hyperintense T2 lesions in the subcortical and cortical regions of the parietal and occipital lobes. • The basal ganglia, brainstem, and cerebellum are commonly involved. • Posterior circulation is commonly involved, and anterior circulation involvement is seen in 
severe cases. Neurological manifestations of preeclampsia include: • Headaches • Convulsions • Cerebral edema • Blindness • Cerebral hemorrhage.

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following are indicators of severe disease in a patient with preeclampsia?
questions.explanation:
Among the given statements, the presence of pulmonary edema, scotoma, or epigastric pain is 
indicative of severe pre-eclampsia. Criteria for diagnosing severe preeclampsia include: Signs and symptoms of significant end-organ dysfunction are: • New-onset cerebral or visual disturbance i.e., photopsia, scotoma, altered mental status, 
and severe headache • Severe, persistent right upper quadrant or epigastric pain, unresponsive to medication and not 
accounted for by an alternative diagnosis (OR) Serum transaminase concentration 2 times upper 
limit of normal. • Thrombocytopenia with platelets <100,000/microL. • Progressive renal insufficiency (serum creatinine >1.1 mg/dL) • Pulmonary edema. 481 
Sold by @itachibot Diastolic 
BP Proteinur

g +/-

questions.question:
Question 14: A patient at 32 weeks of gestation with pre-eclampsia is admitted to your ward. All of the 
following symptoms would warn you of impending eclampsia, except:
questions.explanation:
Decreased deep tendon reflex is not a symptom of impending eclampsia. There will be increased 
deep tendon reflex i.e., hyperreflexia. Symptoms and signs of impending eclampsia include: • Severe occipital or frontal headache • Oliguria - diminished urine output <400 ml/day • Epigastric pain • Visual symptoms - blurring, scotomas, blindness • Disturbed sleep • Ankle clonus • Severe elevation in blood pressure • Pulmonary edema.

questions.question:
Question 15: A G2P1 woman with a history of pre-eclampsia presents at 24 weeks of gestation for an 
antenatal check-up. You decide to evaluate her risk of developing pre-eclampsia in the present 
pregnancy. Which of the following results is not an indicator?

options.a: Absence of diastolic notch on Doppler
options.b: High resistance index in uterine artery Doppler in the second trimester
options.d: Presence of free fetal DNA in maternal serum

questions.explanation:
In this above scenario, the absence of a diastolic notch at 24 weeks on Doppler is not a predictor 
of pre-eclampsia. In normal pregnant women, a diastolic notch in the uterine artery disappears by 24 weeks. Thus, 
a persistent diastolic notch present in uterine artery flow between 22-24 weeks is predictive of 
preeclampsia. Predictors of preeclampsia: • Free fetal DNA in maternal plasma • Diastolic notch present in uterine artery flow between 22-24 weeks (high resistance index in the 
second trimester) • Average MAP >90 mmHg Predictors no longer used include: • Hemoconcentration • Elevated fibronectin 482 
Sold by @itachibot • Increase in uric acid levels • Hypocalciuria - calcium in urine <12mg/dl in 24 h • Increased homocysteine levels • Roll-over test - screening test is done between 28-32 weeks.

questions.question:
Question 16: A 30-year-old G3P2 at 34 weeks of gestation was admitted as her BP was 150/90mmHg and 
urine dipstick was 2+ on antenatal checkup. Which of the following drugs is not suitable to 
control BP in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Captopril is an ACE inhibitor and it is contraindicated in pregnancy. High BP and proteinuria are diagnostic of preeclampsia. The following drugs are used for the 
management of pre-eclampsia. ACE inhibitors inhibit the conversion of angiotensin I to the potent vasoconstrictor angiotensin-II. 
When given in the second and third trimesters, they can cause severe fetal malformations such as: • Bony malformations • Persistent PDA • Respiratory distress syndrome • Limb contracture • Pulmonary hypoplasia. Anti-hypertensives to be avoided in pregnancy include: • ACE inhibitors • Angiotensin receptor blockers • Diuretics (contraindicated as anti-hypertensive but can be given in CCF) • Reserpine • Sodium nitroprusside (used only as a drug of last resort in refractory severe hypertension) • Diazoxide. Drug 
Dose Labetalol 
100 mg TID or ›ID 250–500 mg TID or 
›ID Methyl-d 
opa 10–20 mg BD Nifedipin 
e 10–25 mg BD Hydralaz 
ine

questions.question: Question 17: Which is the drug of choice for controlling BP in a patient with severe pre-eclampsia?
questions.explanation:
483 
Sold by @itachibot Intravenous labetalol is the drug of choice for controlling BP in severe pre-eclampsia. It is the first-line agent for urgent control of BP in pregnancy. It is effective, has a rapid onset of 
action, and has a good safety profile. Labetalol is a nonselective  blocker and vascular  blocker. It should be avoided in patients with 
asthma and congestive heart failure due to bronchoconstriction. Option B: Hydralazine causes maternal hypotension and fetal distress. Option C: Nifedipine causes reflex tachycardia and headache in the mother. Option D: In methyldopa, a change in BP is an indirect action. So it is less effective in controlling 
BP. Note: Experimental antihypertensive drugs for pre-eclampsia treatment are calcitonin 
gene-related peptide (CGRP) and anti-digoxin antibody Fab (DIF). DIF is directed against 
endogenous digitalis-like factors, also called cardiotonic steroids. Choice of anti-hypertensives i 
n pregnancy Labetalol PIH /pre-eclampsia / severe p 
re-eclampsia Acute hypertension/ Hyperte 
nsive crisis IV labetalol, nifedipine, hydr 
alazine Chronic hypertension in preg 
nancy Labetalol > methyl dopa.

questions.question:
Question 18: A G3P1A1, preeclamptic patient at 33 weeks of gestation came for a regular antenatal 
check-up. At present, her BP is 130/90 and an NST is reactive. What is the plan of 
management for this patient? 471 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The scenario is suggestive of mild pre-eclampsia as the patient has a BP of 130/90 mmHg and no 
fetal compromise. Hence, the plan of management would be to wait till 37 weeks for termination. In all cases of hypertension during pregnancy, the preferred mode of delivery is vaginal. Cesarean 
is indicated only for any co-existing obstetrical reasons. Hypertensive condition 
Time of delivery Gestational hypertension 
38–39 weeks Mild pre-eclampsia 
37 weeks Severe pre-eclampsia 
34 weeks Eclampsia, HELLP syndr 
ome Immediate termination irres 
pective of gestational age

questions.question:
Question 19: A 33-week-pregnant lady with pre-eclampsia presents with features suggestive of HELLP 
syndrome. Which of the following is false about her condition?

options.a: Corticosteroids aid in increasing platelet count
options.b: It is characterised by microangiopathic hemolysis
options.c: MgSO4 can be used in the management of HELLP syndrome
options.d: Termination of pregnancy is the definitive management

questions.explanation:
484 
Sold by @itachibot Corticosteroid treatment for thrombocytopenia is not recommended in patients with HELLP 
syndrome. HELLP syndrome is a serious complication in pregnancy characterized by HEmolysis, ELevated 
liver enzymes, and Low Platelet count. It occurs in 0.5-0.9% of all pregnancies and in 10–20% of 
patients with severe preeclampsia. Management of HELLP syndrome is supportive, including: - Antiseizure prophylaxis with MgSO4 - Platelet tansfusion if platelet count <50,000/mm3 , FFP transfusion - Plasmapheresis - Immediate termination of pregnancy in the interest of the mother. The most common cause of maternal death in HELLP syndrome is abruptio placenta and DIC.

questions.question: Question 20: Which among the following is false regarding HELLP syndrome?

options.a: PT, PTT, fibrinogen levels are normal
options.b: All patients with HELLP syndrome have abnormal BP
options.c: Tennessee criteria is used for diagnosis

questions.explanation:
15% of pregnant women with HELLP syndrome have normal blood pressure. HELLP syndrome occurs at 27-37 weeks. PT, PTT, and fibrinogen levels are normal. This differs 
from DIC where PT and PTT are elevated while the plasma fibrinogen level is decreased. Tennessee criteria is used for diagnosis and Mississippi classification is used to grade HELLP 
syndrome. • Tennessee criteria for diagnosis of true/complete HELLP • Platelet count <1 lakh/cu mm • AST >70 I’/L, • LDH >600 I’/L • Mississippi classification divides HELLP into 3 grades based on the platelet count.

questions.question:
Question 21: A G2P1 patient at 25 weeks of gestation is brought to the emergency with right upper 
quadrant pain and one episode of seizure. CBC reveals a Hb of 7.6gm/dl and a platelet count 
of 70,000/microL. What is the definitive management?
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of eclampsia and HELLP syndrome. The definitive management 
is the termination of pregnancy. In cases of pre-eclampsia, indications for termination of pregnancy, irrespective of gestational age, 
are as follows: • Eclampsia (give MgSO4 followed by induction of labor) • HELLP syndrome • Persistent symptoms of severe pre-eclampsia or severe hypertension • Pulmonary edema • Significant renal dysfunction, coagulopathy 485 
Sold by @itachibot • Abruption of placenta • Fetal compromise In mild pre-eclampsia, steroids are given and the patient is delivered at 37 weeks. In severe pre-eclampsia: • If pregnancy is >34 weeks - MgSO4 is given for prophylaxis of eclampsia and the pregnancy is 
terminated. • If pregnancy is at 27-34 weeks - in the absence of contraindications, expectant management is 
followed and the baby is delivered at 34 weeks, as shown below in the flowchart.

questions.question:
Question 22: 472 
Sold by @itachibot A pre-eclamptic patient at 30 weeks of gestation is rushed to the hospital as she suddenly lost 
her vision 1 hour ago. During admission, she has a seizure. Which of the given statements is 
correct?

options.a: Convulsions within 7 days of delivery are called postpartum eclampsia
options.b: Thrombocytosis is likely to be found
options.c: Blindness due to this condition is usually reversible

questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of eclampsia. Blindness due to eclampsia is usually reversible. Blindness due to eclampsia can be due to a central or peripheral cause. It is irreversible only if the 
etiology is a combination of retinal infarction and bilateral lateral geniculate nuclei lesions. Option A: Convulsions within 48 hours of delivery are called postpartum eclampsia. Option B: The most common hematological finding in pregnancy-induced hypertension is 
thrombocytopenia. Option D: The seizures are generalized seizures. Note: The most common cause of death in patients with eclampsia is intracerebral hemorrhage.

questions.question:
Question 23: A G3P2 patient with preeclampsia develops seizures and is started on the Pritchard regimen. 
What level of serum magnesium should be maintained in this patient in order to prevent 
seizures?
questions.explanation:
The clinical picture is suggestive of eclampsia and to control fits, optimum serum magnesium 
levels of 4-7 mEq/L have to be maintained. 486 
Sold by @itachibot MgSO4 regimens for management of eclampsia and severe pre-eclampsia: Regimen

ai)

questions.question: Question 24: The mechanism of action of MgSo4 includes all, except:

options.c: It reduces motor endplate sensitivity to Ach

questions.explanation:
MgSO4 blocks calcium influx, not sodium. Mechanism of action of MgSO4: • It is a membrane stabilizer and acts as a neuroprotector by reducing motor endplate sensitivity 
to Ach. • It blocks neuronal calcium influx. • It reduces the presynaptic release of the neurotransmitter glutamate. • It blocks glutaminergic NMDA receptors and potentiates adenosine action.

questions.question:
Question 25: Which of the following is an indication to skip the next dose in a patient with severe 
pre-eclampsia taking MgSO4 prophylactically?
questions.explanation:
Repeat injections of MgSO4 are given only if knee jerks are present. The next dose of MgSO4 is only given when all signs of magnesium toxicity are absent. Signs of magnesium toxicity: • Loss of deep tendon reflexes • Decreased respiratory rate (<12 per min) • ’rine output <30 ml/hr • Chest pain, heart block Management of magnesium toxicity: • Stop magnesium therapy • Estimation of serum magnesium and creatinine levels • Injection of calcium gluconate 10 ml (10% solution) IV Side effects of MgSO4: • Anuria • Pulmonary edema. 487 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 26: A pregnant woman with pre-eclampsia is started on prophylactic MgSO4 in view of signs of 
impending eclampsia. An hour later, examination reveals RR - 16 breaths/minute and absent 
patellar reflexes. What is her plasma concentration of MgSO4 most likely to be?
questions.explanation:
Patellar reflexes disappear when plasma magnesium concentration reaches 10 mEq/L. As there is 
no respiratory depression, the plasma concentration is likely to be 10-12 mEq/L. The disappearance of the patellar reflex is the first sign of impending magnesium toxicity. MgSO4 
is prophylactically used in impending eclampsia, severe pre-eclampsia, and HELLP syndrome. Plasma concentrations of ma 
gnesium (mEq/L) Signs of magnesium toxicit 
y Loss of patellar reflex 
10–12 Respiratory depression 
12-13 Cardiac arrest 
>30

questions.question: Question 27: Magnesium sulphate has no role in:

options.a: Prevention of seizures in severe pre-eclampsia
options.b: Prevention of recurrent seizures in eclampsia
options.c: Prevention of RDS in premature baby

questions.explanation:
Magnesium sulfate has no role in the prevention of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in a 
premature baby, where there is a deficit of surfactant (which results in alveolar collapse). Magnesium in the MgSO4 competes with calcium on voltage-gated calcium channels, thereby 
altering its uptake and release. Functions of MgSO4 include : • Membrane protector and neuro stabilizer. It is used in the prevention of cerebral palsy in very 
low birth weight neonates. • Reduction of motor endplate sensitivity to acetylcholine, and thus is used as an adjunct in the 
management of acute severe asthma in children and adults • Blocking of neuronal calcium influx, and is thus used in the conservative management of 
pre-term labor (tocolytic, option D) • Inducing cerebral vasodilatation, dilating the uterine arteries, increasing the production of 
endothelial prostacyclin, and inhibiting platelet activation. Hence it is used in the management of 
pre-eclampsia (option A) and to prevent progression to eclampsia (option A).

questions.question:
Question 28: A primigravida at 33 weeks of gestation was rushed to the hospital with recurrent seizures. 
Her husband says that prior to the seizures, she had complained of a headache and visual 
disturbances. She was on antihypertensives from the first trimester and there is no history of 
neurological disease. Which of the following is true regarding her management?

options.a: First step of management is intravenous MgSO4
options.b: Diazepam is recommended as an anticonvulsant if MgSO4 fails
options.c: Treatment may be based on recommendations from the Magpie trial
options.d: Maternal alkalosis commonly occurs and needs correction

questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of eclampsia and management may be based on 
recommendations from the Magpie trial. The Magpie trial showed that prophylactic use of magnesium sulfate lowers the risk of eclampsia. The first step in the management of eclampsia is maintaining the airway, ensuring oxygen 
delivery to both mother and fetus. Then, MgSO4 is administered to control seizures. 488 
Sold by @itachibot Thiopentone > phenobarbitone may be used to control seizures. No attempt should be made to 
shorten the convulsion using diazepam as it often leads to thrombophlebitis and respiratory 
depression. Maternal acidosis usually occurs and is corrected when present.

questions.question: Question 29: Which of the following is true regarding eclampsia?
questions.explanation:
Antepartum eclampsia has the worst prognosis and the most common MRI finding of eclampsia is 
subcortical white matter edema. Antepartum eclampsia is the most common type of eclampsia. It has the highest rate of maternal 
mortality. The outcome of eclampsia depends on the duration of hypertension and not severity. The 
most common cause of death in eclampsia and severe pre-eclampsia is intracranial bleeding.

questions.question:
Question 30: A pregnant lady with PIH was being monitored with bed rest in supine position. Which of the 
following is a complication of the below representation?

options.a: Fasting blood glucose  92 mg/dL is diagnostic
options.b: 100 grams of glucose is given after overnight fast

questions.explanation:
Supine vena cava syndrome is the complication of the given representation. The image shows 
compression of the inferior vena cava by the gravid uterus which can sometimes lead to supine 
hypotension. During late pregnancy, the gravid uterus compresses the great vessels against the hard spine, 
when the patient is in the supine position. Of the two vessels, the vena cava is compressed, but the 
aorta, owing to its structure is relatively resistant. Normally, the vena cava compression results in opening up collateral circulation by means of 
paravertebral and azygous veins but in some cases, when the collateral circulation fails to open 
up, the venous return of the heart may be seriously curtailed resulting in hypotension, 
tachycardia, and syncope and is called supine vena cava syndrome. The normal blood pressure is quickly restored by turning the patient to the lateral position. 489 
Sold by @itachibot Diabetes in Pregnancy
